WRITING.TEXT: But aren't you worried that you are finishing fewer books than you otherwise can?

WRITING.TITLE: How do you read books?
WRITING.TEXT:
I know this might sound stupid at first, but please bear me for a while.
There are two ways to read. First, go word by word. Second, read fast, while soaking in the general idea and not worrying about every emotion or detail.
I tend to take the first route, but at the expense of consuming fewer books. For e.g., in Pride and Prejudice, I have to reread lot of sentences to exactly understand what's going on, because of its archaic style. The same happened with me when I had read The Great Gatsby and Midnight's Children, because of their high-end vocabulary. I limit the second approach for *lighter* novels, such as those by Sidney Sheldon.
At this point, I should clarify that I am not a newbie reader. It is just that I am slowed down by my attempt to soak in everything that the author has to say, and I am now wondering if I should read faster, albeit with lesser comprehension.
So, what do you suggest? How do *you* read books?

I have taken lot of interviews for my company. Two instances stand out:
- I was having a dull day at a recruiting event, because the candidates were all poor. Suddenly, I was sitting in front of this guy from Walmart Labs. I had heard that Walmart Labs asks really difficult questions in its interviews. And since this guy was an employee, and so must have cleared their interview in the past, I couldn't ask him the usual simple questions I was asking all day long. I brought out the big guns, even one difficult question that I had never asked before The candidate didn't disappoint and handled all of them comfortably.
- One of my favourite questions is how to design a monitoring and automated alerting system, on a high level. The problem isn't as easy as it sounds. Needless to say, I have seen lot of folks flounder in it. And I remember a guy who used a stream, such as Kafka, to build the system. He also handled failure scenarios properly. I was impressed!

Awesome! I would have given you a gold, if I had any!
Anyway, keep it up.
Agreed. Start with the ones that are lowest in your order of preference, just to get a hang of things. Keep the difficult ones for a little later.

I agree with everything *except*:
I'd chat with the engineer tomorrow and tell them you're interested, talk about road map, etc. And see if you'd be a good fit.
I'd suggest you first talk to the hiring manager: either ping him to meet you over coffee or setup a short 30 minute 1:1 with him. Find out if he indeed has open positions in his team and what kind of prior experience he is looking for. If you sense he is interested, ask him if there's anyone on his team you could talk to further.
In other words, reach out to the hiring manager *before* talking to someone on his team.

This isn't the same as trying to relocate within a company. For e.g., if the project you are working on goes into maintenance mode, you stop getting quality work. However, you have more context in your current company to find out other projects or teams that are still going strong. If you move to a different firm, it is difficult to judge the work quality of the team that you are about to join or influence the team selection.
All of this is, of course, if your current company itself isn't shitty.
I did it once too- it was difficult, but doable. I'd spend 1-2 hours on weekdays, by solving some problems or reading up some relevant stuff, and 3-6 hours on weekends.
That is a lot IMO. Are you building some product or working in web services world? Because I guess in the latter, 10% time for design meetings won't be enough.
Your case is straightforward- you gotta jump ship the moment you get an opportunity!
Farobek has a point though. The questions folks ask in interviews greatly differ from what you generally use in real life.

WRITING.TITLE: How often do you write code as part of your job?
WRITING.TEXT:

WRITING.TITLE: Hit a weight loss plateau with 16:8
WRITING.TEXT:
Hi, I started 16:8 IF 1.5 to 2 months ago. I went from 77 to 74 kgs in 2-3 weeks, most of which must have been water weight. But since then, I haven't lost any more weight. I have been maintaining my fast periods religiously and have also cut down alcohol to a pint of beer a week.
Any thoughts from experienced folks on this? Would the weight loss begin again after some time?
Yes, it is normal to have stomach pangs in the beginning. They'll quickly go away, in a few days.

In almost all cases, no. If your friend is writing some code outside work, for e.g., on Github, then it might be a different story.

First, you should have put the *TLDR* at the top! Anyway, it's totally OK to not know lot of things in the beginning of the job. What is not OK is that you don't put effort to ramp up, something that is fortunately not the case with you. So, I'd say, 'Relax! And take it easy'. Also, it can be overwhelming to learn so much in such a short time. Rather, start slowly, first with technologies that are needed in the short term on the job, and gradually move on to more things.

WRITING.TITLE: Depth vs Breadth of experience.
WRITING.TEXT:
I am a Software Developer at a big MNC. I have two options in near future:
* Stick with my current team, where I have a decent chance of getting a promotion by next October. Pros: Bigger paycheck after promotion. Cons: I have (sort of) learnt almost everything that is there to be offered. So, won't improve much on technical front. * Screw the promotion and move to some other team, and learn more about a new and (possibly) interesting technical and business domain.
Thoughts?
